questions.question_text: Which three options are reasons for an interface to go into err-disable state? (Choose three.)

choices.F: grouping ports into a port channel
choices.C: hard-coded speed duplex match on both sides

discussion.content:
This is output from Catalyst 3750E:

"SW(config)#errdisable detect cause ?
 all Enable error detection on all cases
 arp-inspection Enable error detection for arp inspection
 bpduguard Enable error detection on bpdu-guard
 dhcp-rate-limit Enable error detection on dhcp-rate-limit
 dtp-flap Enable error detection on dtp-flapping
 gbic-invalid Enable error detection on gbic-invalid
 inline-power Enable error detection for inline-power
 l2ptguard Enable error detection on l2protocol-tunnel
 link-flap Enable error detection on linkstate-flapping
 loopback Enable error detection on loopback
 pagp-flap Enable error detection on pagp-flapping
 pppoe-ia-rate-limit Enable error detection on PPPoE IA rate-limit
 psp Enable error detection on PSP
 security-violation Enable error detection on 802.1x-guard
 sfp-config-mismatch Enable error detection on SFP config mismatch
 small-frame Enable error detection on small_frame

SW(config)#"

It is full output of the command. There is no storm-control on the list.

comments.content:
Yes. It's the incorrect/unclear question from Cisco as usual.
The list of err-disable reasons depends on an IOS version and a platform.

questions.question_text: Which command enables root guard on a cisco switch?

discussion.content:
Answer A
Interface level 
switch(config-if)# spanning-tree guard root

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. Which statement describes the result if a switch that is running PVST+ is added to this network?
//IMG//

discussion.content: Graphic is it missing rstp from the 'spanning-tree enabled protocol' line?

choices.B: Spanning tree continues to operate in Rapid PVST+ on DSW2 and the new switch operates in PVST+
choices.A: Spanning tree is disabled automatically on the network
choices.D: Both switches operate in the Rapid PVST+ mode B
choices.C: Both switches operate in the PVST+ mode

choices.A: Configure VLAN 500 & VLAN 600 on both SW1 & SW2
choices.C: Configure VLAN 500 and VLAN 600 on SW2 only
choices.D: Configure VLAN 500 and VLAN 600 on SW1 ,SW2 and SW4
choices.E: On SW2; configure vtp mode as off and configure VLAN 500 and VLAN 600; configure back to vtp server mode.
choices.B: Configure VLAN 500 and VLAN 600 on SW1 only

questions.answer_description: By issuing the show vtp status command on SW2, SW2, and SW4 we see that both SW1 and SW2 are operating in VTP server mode, but SW4 is a client, so we will need to add both VLANs to SW1 and SW2.

discussion.content: Correct answer is B, as SW1 is primary server. We cannot configure VLAN on non-primary server. And we no need.
